questions.text: A 57-year-old female with severe Inflammatory Arthritis and on long term medications for treatment of Osteoporosis suddenly presented in emergency with pain in thigh with Inability to ambulate. X-Rays were performed as below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Atypical Fracture

Explanation:

  • • Explanation for each option:
  • • Option A. Atypical Fracture. The X-ray shows features of an atypical femoral fracture. Atypical fractures of the femur are associated with long-term use of bisphosphonates, which are commonly prescribed for the treatment of osteoporosis. These fractures typically occur in the subtrochanteric or diaphyseal region of the femur and have distinct radiographic features, including transverse or short oblique patterns with medial cortical thickening and lateral cortical beaking. The patient's clinical history of osteoporosis medication use and the location and appearance of the fracture are consistent with this diagnosis.
  • • Option A. Atypical Fracture.
  • • Option B. Typical Subtrochanteric Fracture. This option is not supported by the X-ray findings, as the fracture does not appear to be a typical subtrochanteric fracture. Typical subtrochanteric fractures are often associated with trauma or osteoporosis but do not exhibit the atypical features seen in this X-ray.
  • • Option B. Typical Subtrochanteric Fracture.
  • • Option C. Paget's Disease of Bone. Paget's disease of bone can cause bone deformities and fractures, but the X-ray findings do not show the characteristic appearance of Paget's disease, which includes areas of increased bone density and disorganized bone structure.
  • • Option C. Paget's Disease of Bone.
  • • Option D. Malignancy of the Bone. While malignancies can lead to pathological fractures, the X-ray findings do not show the typical features of bone malignancies, such as destructive bone lesions or soft tissue masses.
  • • Option D. Malignancy of the Bone.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient undergoes an elective laparoscopic cholecystectomy. He has a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and smokes one pack of cigarettes daily. Anesthesia is induced without any complications, and the patient is intubated using a cuffed endotracheal tube. During the surgical procedure, you notice a change in the capnography waveform. Instead of a normal square waveform, there is a gradual upslope during the expiratory phase and a decreased end-tidal CO2 (ETCO2) value. Based on the capnography findings, what is the most likely explanation for the observed changes?

options.label: C
options.text: Airway obstruction or increased airway resistance

options.label: D
options.text: Equipment malfunction in the CO2 monitoring system

questions.correct_answer: C. Airway obstruction or increased airway resistance
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Airway obstruction or increased airway resistance

Explanation:

  • • Explanation for each option:
  • • Option A. Kinked endotracheal tube . A kinked endotracheal tube can lead to significant resistance in the airway, but it typically results in a complete blockage of the airway, causing a sudden and complete loss of CO2 waveform. The gradual upslope observed in this case is not consistent with a kinked tube.
  • • Option A. Kinked endotracheal tube
  • • Option B. Hyperventilation . Hyperventilation typically leads to a decrease in ETCO2 values, but it doesn't cause a gradual upslope during the expiratory phase. Instead, it results in a faster exhalation of CO2 and a steeper downslope of the waveform.
  • • Option B. Hyperventilation
  • • Option C. Airway obstruction or increased airway resistance . This is the most likely explanation for the observed changes in the capnography waveform. Increased airway resistance or partial airway obstruction can cause a gradual upslope during the expiratory phase as the exhalation of CO2 is slowed down or impeded. This is often seen as a characteristic waveform change in conditions like bronchospasm or when there is a partial obstruction in the airway.
  • • Option C. Airway obstruction or increased airway resistance
  • • Option D. Equipment malfunction in the CO2 monitoring system . While equipment malfunction is a possibility, it's less likely in this case because the gradual upslope and decreased ETCO2 values are indicative of a physiological change in the patient's airway, such as increased resistance or partial obstruction. Equipment malfunction would typically result in an erratic or non-interpretable waveform rather than the specific changes described.
  • • Option D. Equipment malfunction in the CO2 monitoring system

With their feeble inspiratory effort, some fresh gas sucked from the ventilator tubing and past the capnometer, generating this pattern.   • • 4. A low end-tidal CO 2 in hypothermia:
  • • In hypothermia, the total body CO 2 production is greatly decreased (as the metabolic rate is decreased by 6% for every degree below 36°). The end-tidal CO2 in these people will be unnaturally low. This can be seen in a number of other conditions. For instance, a low-cardiac-output state generates a low end-tidal CO 2 because there is simply not enough flow across the pulmonary circulation. Or, alternatively, deep anaesthesia and muscle paralysis will result in a similar picture.

  • • 5. A high peak of the alveolar phase in poorly compliant lungs:
  • • This pattern is called a " pigtail " capnogram. It is typically seen in poor lung compliance, but it can also occur in pregnant women and obese patients. Essentially, the sudden peak of pre-inspiratory expired CO 2 is due to sudden airway closure. It occurs when a poorly compliant lung (or a huge fat chest wall, or a big pregnant belly) crushes the last few milliliters of CO 2 -rich gas from the alveoli before the collapse of the lung parenchyma also occludes the small bronchi and puts an end to the escape of gas.

A 28-year-old woman presents with infertility and is diagnosed with anovulatory cycles. Which of the following medications can be used for ovulation induction in this patient?
questions.correct_answer: C. Both clomiphene citrate and letrozole
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Both clomiphene citrate and letrozole

Explanation:

  • • Explanation of all options:
  • • Option A. Clomiphene citrate is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) that blocks the negative feedback of estrogen on the hypothalamus, leading to increased production and release of follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) and luteinizing hormone (LH). This promotes follicular growth and ovulation.
  • • Option A. Clomiphene citrate
  • • Option B. Letrozole is an aromatase inhibitor that reduces the conversion of androgens to estrogen, leading to decreased estrogen levels and increased FSH production. It has been found to be equally effective or even superior to clomiphene citrate in some cases, particularly in women with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS).
  • • Option B. Letrozole
  • • Option D. Gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) agonists are not typically used for primary ovulation induction. They are more commonly used to suppress ovulation temporarily in certain fertility treatment protocols or for medical management of specific conditions, such as endometriosis.
  • • Option D. Gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) agonists

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Drug of choice in infertility in a woman with anovulation : Letrozole (PCOS) and Clomiphene citrate) Gonadotropins are the 2 nd line management in anovulation in infertility.

questions.text: A woman presents with a breast tumor of size 6 x 3cm, with adherence to the pectoralis major muscle. Overlying skin shows dimpling. As her surgeon, what will you designate her T staging as?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. T3

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Irrelevant to the size of the tumor, if the tumor shows extension to the chest wall or skin, it is classified as T4. However, there are two exceptions. Invasion or adherence to pectoralis muscle in the absence of chest wall involvement does not qualify as T4. Similarly, involvement of the dermis in the form of dimpling/puckering/retraction of nipple does not qualify as T4.
  • ➤ Irrelevant to the size of the tumor, if the tumor shows extension to the chest wall or skin, it is classified as T4. However, there are two exceptions.
  • ➤ Invasion or adherence to pectoralis muscle in the absence of chest wall involvement does not qualify as T4.
  • ➤ Similarly, involvement of the dermis in the form of dimpling/puckering/retraction of nipple does not qualify as T4.
  • ➤ Points to Remember:
  • ➤ Points to Remember:
  • ➤ In tumor size assessment, the greatest dimension is taken into consideration. For example, in a 6 X 3 cm lump, 6 cm is taken into account, and the tumor is classified as T3 (>5 cm). Skin involvement does not include nipple retraction and skin dimpling. Supraclavicular lymph node involvement indicates N3c. Any contralateral lymph node involvement is considered as distant metastasis. If 2 lumps are present in the same breast, staging is according to the bigger lump. If lumps are present in both breasts, separate staging is done for both the lumps.
  • ➤ In tumor size assessment, the greatest dimension is taken into consideration. For example, in a 6 X 3 cm lump, 6 cm is taken into account, and the tumor is classified as T3 (>5 cm).
  • ➤ Skin involvement does not include nipple retraction and skin dimpling.
  • ➤ Supraclavicular lymph node involvement indicates N3c.
  • ➤ Any contralateral lymph node involvement is considered as distant metastasis.
  • ➤ If 2 lumps are present in the same breast, staging is according to the bigger lump.
  • ➤ If lumps are present in both breasts, separate staging is done for both the lumps.

questions.text: A 43-year-old patient presented in OPD with complaints of pain in wrist around Radial styloid with difficulty in performing activities of daily living. What is the clinical test demonstrated below to diagnose this condition is?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Finkelstein’s Test

Explanation:

  • • Explanation for each option:
  • • Option B. Finkelstein's Test. This test is specifically used to diagnose De Quervain's tenosynovitis. During the test, the patient makes a fist with the thumb inside the fingers, and the wrist is ulnarly deviated. The examiner then stabilizes the patient's forearm, and the patient is asked to move the wrist into radial deviation. A positive test result is indicated by pain over the radial styloid, which suggests inflammation of the tendons of the abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis, characteristic of De Quervain's tenosynovitis.
  • • Option B. Finkelstein's Test.
  • • Option A. Cozen's Test. Cozen's test is used to assess lateral epicondylitis (tennis elbow) and involves resisted wrist extension with the elbow extended and the wrist in pronation. It is not related to De Quervain's tenosynovitis.
  • • Option A. Cozen's Test.
  • • Option C. Reverse Cozen's Test. "Reverse Cozen's Test" is not a recognized clinical test. It is not related to either De Quervain's tenosynovitis or any other specific condition.
  • • Option C. Reverse Cozen's Test.
  • • Option D. Phalen's Test. Phalen's test is used to assess carpal tunnel syndrome and involves flexing the wrist and holding it in a flexed position for a minute to reproduce symptoms. It is not specific to De Quervain's tenosynovitis.
  • • Option D. Phalen's Test.

questions.text: A patient with a history of severe asthma is scheduled for an appendectomy. Which of the following induction agents will cause the least respiratory depression?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Ketamine

Explanation:

  • • Explanation for each option:
  • • Option A. Ketamine . Ketamine is known for its bronchodilator properties and minimal respiratory depression. It can actually stimulate the respiratory drive and maintain airway reflexes, making it a suitable choice for patients with asthma. Ketamine is often preferred for induction in patients with bronchospastic diseases like asthma.
  • • Option A. Ketamine
  • • Option B. Propofol . Propofol is a commonly used induction agent, but it can cause respiratory depression. It is not the best choice for a patient with a history of severe asthma as it may further suppress respiratory function.
  • • Option B. Propofol
  • • Option C. Etomidate . Etomidate is generally considered a good choice for induction in patients with compromised respiratory function because it has a relatively mild impact on respiration. However, ketamine is still a better choice for asthma patients due to its bronchodilatory effects.
  • • Option C. Etomidate
  • • Option D. Thiopental . Thiopental, like propofol, can cause respiratory depression and is not the ideal choice for a patient with a history of severe asthma.
  • • Option D. Thiopental
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Ketamine is the most suitable induction agent for a patient with severe asthma because it has bronchodilator properties and causes minimal respiratory depression, making it less likely to exacerbate asthma symptoms during induction.
  • • Ketamine is the most suitable induction agent for a patient with severe asthma because it has bronchodilator properties and causes minimal respiratory depression, making it less likely to exacerbate asthma symptoms during induction.

A person comes with fracture tibia with swelling of lower leg pulse feeble but palpable. Intacompatmental pressure is raised. What is the next step in management?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Fasciotomy

Explanation:

  • • Explanation for each option:
  • • Option A. Fasciotomy. In cases of tibia fractures associated with swelling, a compromised vascular supply, and elevated compartment pressure, there is a risk of compartment syndrome. Compartment syndrome occurs when increased pressure within a closed anatomical compartment (such as the leg) impairs blood flow, potentially leading to tissue ischemia and necrosis. A feeble but palpable pulse is an indication that blood flow is compromised. The definitive treatment for compartment syndrome is fasciotomy, which involves making a surgical incision to relieve pressure within the affected compartment, thereby restoring blood flow and preventing tissue damage.
  • • Option A. Fasciotomy.
  • • Option B. External fixation. External fixation may be considered in certain cases, but it does not address the issue of compartment syndrome directly. It is typically used to stabilize the fracture temporarily and may not relieve the pressure within the compartment.
  • • Option B. External fixation.
  • • Option C. Interlock nail. Intramedullary nailing (interlock nail) is a surgical technique used to stabilize the fractured bone but does not directly address compartment syndrome or elevated compartment pressures.
  • • Option C. Interlock nail.
  • • Option D. Lower limb venography. Lower limb venography is not the primary diagnostic or therapeutic option for compartment syndrome. It is used to evaluate the venous system and is not indicated in the acute management of a tibia fracture with signs of compartment syndrome.
  • • Option D. Lower limb venography.

A patient with a severe clotting disorder presents with prolonged bleeding following minor trauma. Laboratory investigations reveal deficiencies in multiple clotting factors. Among these factors, which of the following pairs correctly represents two consecutive activated clotting factors within the intrinsic pathway of the coagulation cascade?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Factor XIa → Factor IXa

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Option A (Factor VIIIa → Factor IXa) : Incorrect. Factor VIIIa is an activator of Factor IX, but Factor IXa does not follow Factor VIIIa in the cascade; rather, it is the other way around.
  • • Option A (Factor VIIIa → Factor IXa)
  • • Option B (Factor Xa → Factor XIa) : Incorrect. Factor Xa is downstream of Factor XIa in the coagulation cascade. Factor XIa activates Factor IX, which ultimately leads to the activation of Factor X.
  • • Option B (Factor Xa → Factor XIa)
  • • Option C (Factor XIIa → Factor VIIa) : Incorrect. Factor XIIa is part of the intrinsic pathway, while Factor VIIa is part of the extrinsic pathway. They do not directly follow each other in the coagulation cascade.
  • • Option C (Factor XIIa → Factor VIIa)
  • • Option D (Factor XIa → Factor IXa) : Correct. In the intrinsic pathway of the coagulation cascade, Factor XIa activates Factor IX to Factor IXa. Factor IXa then forms a complex with Factor VIIIa to activate Factor X to Factor Xa, which is a critical step in the pathway leading to thrombin formation and fibrin clot.
  • • Option D (Factor XIa → Factor IXa)

questions.text: A patient on chemotherapy was administered an antiemetic to control nausea. Subsequently, the patient developed symptoms including acute dystonia, bradykinesia, and tremors. Which of the following antiemetic medications is most likely to have caused these symptoms?

  • • Option A. Ondansetron . It is a 5-HT receptor antagonist and is considered as drug of choice for nausea and vomiting caused by cancer chemotherapy. It is generally well-tolerated and not known to cause extrapyramidal symptoms like dystonia or bradykinesia.
  • • Option A.
  • • Ondansetron
  • • Option C. Meclizine . It is an antihistaminic drug that is commonly used for motion sickness and vertigo. It is not associated with extrapyramidal symptoms.
  • • Option C.
  • • Meclizine
  • • Option D. Scopolamine . It is an anticholinergic agent used for motion sickness. It can cause dry mouth, blurred vision, and urinary retention, but is not associated with extrapyramidal side effects like dystonia or bradykinesia.
  • • Option D.
  • • Scopolamine

questions.text: Mineralocorticoid receptors are present in all of the following sites, except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Liver

Explanation:

  • • Explanation of each option:
  • • Option A. Hippocampus. Mineralocorticoid receptors are present in the hippocampus, which is a region of the brain. These receptors play a role in regulating the effects of mineralocorticoids (such as aldosterone) on neuronal function and memory.
  • • Option A. Hippocampus.
  • • Option B. Kidney. The kidney is a well-known site for mineralocorticoid receptors. Aldosterone, a mineralocorticoid hormone, acts on these receptors in the kidney to regulate salt and water balance, as well as blood pressure.
  • • Option B. Kidney.
  • • Option C. Colon. Mineralocorticoid receptors are also present in the colon. In the colon, these receptors are involved in regulating sodium and potassium transport, which can affect fluid and electrolyte balance.
  • • Option C. Colon.

A 52-year-old male with Autosomal Dominant Polycystic Kidney Disease (ADPKD) was started on tolvaptan therapy. A few weeks later, he presents with symptoms of dry mouth and increased thirst. What is the likely mechanism behind these symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Increased free water clearance

Explanation:

  • • Explanation of All Other Options:
  • • Option B. V2 receptor agonism. Tolvaptan is a V2 receptor antagonist, not an agonist. Its mechanism of action is to block the V2 receptor, thereby increasing water excretion.
  • • Option B. V2 receptor agonism.
  • • Option C. Increased renal cAMP levels. Vasopressin usually acts on the V2 receptor to increase cAMP levels, which in turn promotes water reabsorption in the collecting duct. Since tolvaptan is a V2 receptor antagonist, it would be expected to decrease cAMP levels in the kidney, not increase them.
  • • Option C. Increased renal cAMP levels.
  • • Option D. Increase in urine osmolality. Tolvaptan's action leads to increased water excretion without a significant change in solute excretion, resulting in a decrease in urine osmolality, not an increase.
  • • Option D. Increase in urine osmolality.
